Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A major supplier has threatened to halt all future shipments until a significant past-due invoice is settled.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to dial the supplier’s number. It was Jamie, my closest friend, her voice trembling. “Can you talk? I really need someone right now,” she said, barely holding back tears. I could hear the pain in her words, and I knew she needed me to listen, to be present, to help her untangle the mess of her argument with her partner. But on my desk, the red-flagged invoice glared at me—a supplier threatening to cut us off if I didn’t resolve the payment immediately. My boss had emailed twice already, expecting a quick response. I felt my chest tighten. Jamie needed my empathy and undivided attention, but my job demanded urgency and focus. I wanted to be the friend she could count on, but I also couldn’t risk jeopardizing the company’s operations. My mind raced, torn between the comfort I owed my friend and the responsibility I owed my employer, both expecting me to be fully present, right now.
